Authors: Minson S.L.; Leiker J.A.; Fross D.A.; Stiles T.L.
Title: Targeting HUC 12s with water samples & windshields
Source title: ASABE - TMDL 2010: Watershed Management to Improve Water Quality
Affiliations: Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watershed Restoration and Protection Strategy (WRAPS) Project, United States; Watershed Planning Section, Kansas Department of Health and the Environment (KDHE), United States
Authors with affiliations: Minson S.L., Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watershed Restoration and Protection Strategy (WRAPS) Project, United States; Leiker J.A., Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watershed Restoration and Protection Strategy (WRAPS) Project, United States; Fross D.A., Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watershed Restoration and Protection Strategy (WRAPS) Project, United States; Stiles T.L., Watershed Planning Section, Kansas Department of Health and the Environment (KDHE), United States
Abstract: The Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watershed Restoration And Protection Strategies (WRAPS) project started in 2003 to protect and improve water resources draining into Kanopolis Reservoir. Kanopolis has a state designated use for municipal and industrial water and supplies 400 million gallons per year to the service area. Its watershed drainage of 2,439 square miles (or two Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC) 8s), with limited historical characterization, presents problems in determining origination of total nitrogen (TN), total phosphorus (TP), total suspended solids (TSS)/sediment, and E. coli bacteria; thus creating the need for extensive water quality monitoring, subwatershed (HUC 12) condition analysis, and Best Management Practices (BMPs) targeting. Monitoring of 41 sites was started in 2007. After 2.5 years, sites were reduced to 31 sites that pinpointed loading and started targeting at the HUC 12 level. The Landon Creek HUC 12 (#102600060401- 35,117 acres, 59% cropland) was targeted in 2009-2010 as analysis indicated Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) impairments and high contributions during storm events. The impairment in overall median water quality was from TN. Yet, the main issue was within storm flow events. Using storm flow means, TN, TP, and TSS values were the highest of all 41 sites. Characterization of subwatersheds is critical to effectively using cost share dollars in order to reduce loading. Building on the monitoring program, we undertook a windshield watershed conditions driving tour using a custom GIS assessment tool, the Western Kansas Cropland Assessment Tool (WKCAT), to spatially characterize subwatersheds by common land units (CLUs). WKCAT was developed to meet the data management and analysis needs of the Big Creek Middle Smoky Hill River Watersheds and is available for download at http://sites.google.com/site/wkcathome/home. With a tablet computer and Arc View 3.3 software, we drove the targeted Landon Creek HUC 12 subwatershed while spatially assessing crop and tillage practices, rangeland conditions, visible erosion, and best management practices. The field conditions were entered in an assessment form and saved in the attribute table of the CLU shapefile. After the data was collected the shapefile was used with GIS software to create cartographs depicting the conditions of the subwatershed and used in conjunction with other geospatial erosion models and equations such as the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE). This assessment method quickly targeted areas in need of load reduction practices such as terraces, waterways, and filter strips. The next step in order to reduce loading is to get the landowners and operators of the Landon Creek HUC 12 together and encourage participation in implementing BMPs. From this group of neighbors, direct decisions will be made on how to best spend demonstration dollars for TMDL reductions within the Landon Creek HUC 12.
Author Keywords: Best Management Practice (BMP); Common Land Units (CLU); E. coli bacteria; Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC); Impairments; Modeling; Nitrogen; Phosphorus; Sediment; Subwatershed; Targeting; Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL); Water quality monitoring

Authors: Gopal Naik M.
Author full names: Gopal Naik, M. (58106080200)
Title: GIS based rainfall-runoff modelling for agricultural watershed
Source title: 28th Asian Conference on Remote Sensing 2007, ACRS 2007
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University College of Engineering (A), Osmania University, Hyderabad-500007, India
Authors with affiliations: Gopal Naik M., Department of Civil Engineering, University College of Engineering (A), Osmania University, Hyderabad-500007, India
Abstract: Due to complexity of the hydrological processes in any of the watersheds, watershed modelling requires advanced computational techniques and data management tools like, Finite Element Method (FEM), Remote Sensing (RS) and Geographical Information Systems (GIS). In this investigation rainfall-runoff model has been developed based on Kinematic Wave Approximation (KWA) using FEM, Remote Sensing and GIS techniques for overland and channel flow. The FEM technique has been applied to solve the partial differential equation of conservation of mass and conservation of linear momentum governing the hydrologic processes. Remotely sensed data has been used to extract Land Use/Land Cover map of the watershed. Thematic maps have been generated using GIS environment. In this paper, a kinematic wave based distributed watershed model using finite element method, remotely sensed data and geographical information systems based approach is presented for the runoff simulation of Khadakohol watershed. The kinematic wave equations are solved using FEM for overland and channel flow to generate runoff at the outlet of the watershed. Green-Ampt Mein Larson (GAML) model is used for the estimation of infiltration. The GIS has been used to prepare finite element grid and input files such as Manning's roughness and slope. The developed distributed watershed model has been applied to the Khadakohol watershed located in Nashik distrct, Maharashtra state, India. It is observed from the results that, the developed rainfall-runoff model has been found to produce satisfactory results for the data selected for the calibration and validation events of Khadakohol watershed. The simulated results are also compared with observed data. The developed model is useful in generating the hydrographs for agricultural watershed.

Authors: Chen X.; Wu C.; Tao Y.; Wu J.; Yang P.; Han Y.
Title: SIT-based LUCC assessment system for sustainable agriculture development in western China methodology and case study
Source title: International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Institute of RS and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Science and Technology Committee, Xinjiang Production and Construction Group, Urumqi 830002, Xinjiang, China; Science and Technology Committee, Xinjiang Production and Construction Group, Shihezi 800032, Xinjiang, China; College of Information and Electrical Engineering, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen X., Institute of RS and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Wu C., Institute of RS and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Tao Y., Institute of RS and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Wu J., Science and Technology Committee, Xinjiang Production and Construction Group, Urumqi 830002, Xinjiang, China; Yang P., Science and Technology Committee, Xinjiang Production and Construction Group, Shihezi 800032, Xinjiang, China; Han Y., College of Information and Electrical Engineering, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China
Abstract: Land use, cover and change (LUCC) assessment is a very important topic for both governmental sectors and institutions in China. In this paper, several typical LUCC programs in China was introduced, and the methodology was discussed for spatial information technology (SIT) applications in LUCC and sustainable agriculture development (SAD) such as data collection and update by RS and GNSS, data management and analysis by GIS, impact analysis of LUCC on SAD and model development for SAD decision making. As an example, a case study was designed and proposed for developing a LUCCSAD system in Xinjiang, western China. The general objective of the proposed study is to build an integrated system (platform), including spatial information acquiring, processing, decision making and services platform to provide timely LUCC information for decision makers of different sectors, farmers, researchers, and so on. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Cressman K.
Author full names: Cressman, Keith (6506372753)
Title: Role of remote sensing in desert locust early warning
Source title: Journal of Applied Remote Sensing
Affiliations: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, Viale delle Terme di Caracalla, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cressman K., Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, Viale delle Terme di Caracalla, Italy
Abstract: Desert locust (Schistocerca gregaria, Forskål) plagues have historically had devastating consequences on food security in Africa and Asia. The current strategy to reduce the frequency of plagues and manage desert locust infestations is early warning and preventive control. To achieve this, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations operates one of the oldest, largest, and best-known migratory pest monitoring systems in the world. Within this system, remote sensing plays an important role in detecting rainfall and green vegetation. Despite recent technological advances in data management and analysis, communications, and remote sensing, monitoring desert locusts and preventing plagues in the years ahead will continue to be a challenge from a geopolitical and financial standpoint for affected countries and the international donor community. We present an overview of the use of remote sensing in desert locust early warning. © 2013 Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers.

Authors: Rovira-Más F.
Author full names: Rovira-Más, Francisco (22952133300)
Title: Stereoscopic vision for off-road intelligent vehicles
Source title: Robotics: Concepts, Methodologies, Tools, and Applications
Affiliations: Polytechnic University of Valencia, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Rovira-Más F., Polytechnic University of Valencia, Spain
Abstract: After mechanization, the next disruptive technology in agriculture will probably be robotization. The introduction of information technology and automation in farm fields started in the eighties with the advent of the Global Positioning System (GPS) and the subsequent development of Precision Agriculture. While being indispensable for many innovative applications, global positioning is not sufficient for all situations encountered in the field, where local sensing is essential if accurate and updated, information has to control automated vehicles. Safeguarding, high resolution mapping, and real time monitoring can only be achieved with local perception sensors such as cameras, lasers, and sonar rangers. However, machine vision offers multiple advantages over other sensing alternatives, and among imaging sensors, stereo vision provides the richest source of information for real time actuation. This chapter presents an overview of current and future applications of 3D stereo vision to off-road intelligent vehicles, with special emphasis in real problems found in agricultural environments and practical solutions devised to cope with them, as image noise, system configuration, and 3D data management. Several examples of stereo perception engines implemented in robotized off-road vehicles illustrate the concepts introduced along the chapter. © 2014, IGI Global. All rights reserved.

Authors: Griffin T.
Author full names: Griffin, Terry (24537061200)
Title: Making the most of yield monitor data for field-scale on-farm experiments
Source title: American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers Annual International Meeting 2009, ASABE 2009
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness, University of Arkansas, Division of Agriculture, Little Rock, AR 72204, 2301 S University Ave, United States
Authors with affiliations: Griffin T., Department of Agricultural Economics and Agribusiness, University of Arkansas, Division of Agriculture, Little Rock, AR 72204, 2301 S University Ave, United States
Abstract: The commercialization of precision agriculture technologies has led to resurgence in field-scale on-farm experimentation by farmers and researchers. Although the cost of implementing experiments and collecting data has decreased due to innovative use of geospatial technologies, barriers to making the best farm management decisions based on field experiments remain. The most recent statistics of farmers' adoption and use of yield monitors are reported. Based on theory and experiences from a four-year case study of farmers using yield monitor data, this study reports how the most successful farmers and researchers make use of precision agriculture in their decision-making process. Topics include designing and implementing appropriate field-scale experiments conducive to the landscape and chosen treatments, collecting and managing data, qualities desired by farmers in a reputable spatial data analyst, and using on-farm trial results in the farm management decision-making process. Yield monitor data quality impacts the farm management decision. Typical yield monitor data analysis may use data subjected to a default correction process of farm level software. Recent advances to farm level software include the integration of professional data filtering capabilities. Results from both traditional aspatial and spatial analyses of differing levels of yield data quality are discussed including: 1) accepting default settings from a range of popular standard farm software packages and 2) a conscious removal of erroneous points and flow delay adjustments. The decisions that the rational farm manager would make for each of these scenarios are presented, addressing the question of the economic importance of quality yield data.

Authors: Lei Z.; Allen G.; Chakraborty P.; Huang D.; Lewis J.; Li X.; White C.D.
Author full names: Lei, Zhou (59035107700); Allen, Gabrielle (57209315298); Chakraborty, Promita (57197288231); Huang, Dayong (13605844200); Lewis, John (57198518623); Li, Xin (56162299200); White, Christopher D. (57212694635)
Title: A Grid-enabled problem-solving environment for advanced reservoir uncertainty analysis
Source title: Concurrency and Computation: Practice and Experience
Affiliations: Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Department of Petroleum Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, 350 Johnston Hall, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lei Z., Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States, Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, 350 Johnston Hall, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Allen G., Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Chakraborty P., Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Huang D., Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Lewis J., Center for Computation and Technology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Li X., Department of Petroleum Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; White C.D., Department of Petroleum Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States
Abstract: Uncertainty analysis is critical for conducting reservoir performance prediction. However, it is challenging because it relies on (1) massive modeling-related, geographically distributed, terabyte, or even petabyte scale data sets (geoscience and engineering data), (2) needs to rapidly perform hundreds or thousands of flow simulations, being Identical runs with different models calculating the impacts of various uncertainty factors, (3) an integrated, secure, and easy-to-use problem-solving toolkit to assist uncertainty analysis. We leverage Grid computing technologies to address these challenges. We design and implement an integrated problem-solving environment ResGrid to effectively improve reservoir uncertainty analysis. The ResGrid consists of data management, execution management, and a Grid portal. Data Grid tools, such as metadata, replica, and transfer services, are used to meet massive size and geographically distributed characteristics of data sets. Workflow, task farming, and resource allocation are used to support large-scale computation. A Grid portal integrates the data management and the computation solution into a unified easy-to-use interface, enabling reservoir engineers to specify uncertainty factors of interest and perform large-scale reservoir studies through a web browser. The ResGrid has been used in petroleum engineering. Copyright © 2008 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: Klindtworth M.
Author full names: Klindtworth, Michael (6507263658)
Title: Electronic in cattle husbandry - From electronic identification to health management: State of the art and perspectives; [Elektronikeinsatz in der Rinderhaltung - Von der elektronischen Tierkennzeichnung zum Gesundheitsmanagement: Aktueller Stand und Entwicklungsperspektiven]
Source title: VDI Berichte
Affiliations: Fachhochschule Osnabrück, Germany; Fachhochschule Osnabrück, Fak. Agrarwiss./L., 49090 Oldenburg, Oldenburger Landstr. 24, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Klindtworth M., Fachhochschule Osnabrück, Germany, Fachhochschule Osnabrück, Fak. Agrarwiss./L., 49090 Oldenburg, Oldenburger Landstr. 24, Germany
Abstract: The use of electronic identification (EID) in cattle husbandry will get more and more importance because of the enormous structural change in agriculture and the related automatisation. It is expected to be established as a basic technology for the relation of automatically recorded sensor-data to an individual animal. With the continuous development of microelectronic components, the avaibility and use of sensors in agriculture will increase, too. This will lead to a cheaper measurement of direct and indirect health parameters such as: body temperature, animal activity, animal weight, milk yield, conductivity of milk, intake of concentrate and rouphage, behavioural aspects etc. Biological processes are very complex in most cases and they are influenced by interacting external effects. As a consequence sensor-based data should not be interpreted as a single parameter, but need to be seen in a whole context. In order to derive any decision, special and expert knowledge is required to calculate and to analyse the available data from different sensors in an adequate way. Further developments of hard- and software will not stop with an accurate description of the "status quo". It is rather expected, that predicting information systems will be developed. First steps can be seen by investigations of "neural nets", "fuzzi logic" and "data mining"-processes. The increasing availability and the use of internet applications in agriculture support new methods of collecting and processing data. Besides the use of data on local, decentral farm computers it is possible to transfer them to a central, data-management-plattform, with defined access for the farmer (and other user groups such as consultants or veterinarians). It remains open whether this technique can be established in future.
Index Keywords: Automation; Data acquisition; Data processing; Health care; Microelectronic processing; Neural networks; Sensors; Behavioural aspects; Cattles; Data management platform; Electronic identification; Agriculture

Authors: Li G.; Xiao K.
Title: Research on water resources decision support system integrated with facilities
Source title: Proceedings 2011 International Conference on Mechatronic Science, Electric Engineering and Computer, MEC 2011
Affiliations: College of Geosciences, Yangtze University, Jingzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Li G., College of Geosciences, Yangtze University, Jingzhou, China; Xiao K., College of Geosciences, Yangtze University, Jingzhou, China
Abstract: Water Resources and Facilities closely linked to Agricultural production is one of critical factors of restricting sustainable development. The existing system has not integrated all of the spatial data about water resources. This article introduces design and implementation of water resources Decision supports system integrated with facilities in detail. The system design goal and basic principle are put forward firstly. Then the system function is analyzed including map operation, data management, data query, buffer analyze and thematic-map editing, flood simulation, and so on. It is tested with the spatial data of Jingzhou city after implemented based on SuperMap. The result shows that the system can provide decision supports for managers such as the flood control and drainage scheduling, water conservancy construction and water resource analysis. © 2011 IEEE.

Authors: Jha B.K.; Jha S.K.; Mukherjee R.; Basak D.
Title: Development of guided SMS solution in local languages for demand-driven access of agricultural information
Source title: 2015 7th International Conference on Communication Systems and Networks, COMSNETS 2015 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Birsa Agricultural University, Ranchi, Kanke, Jharkhand, 834008, India; Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, Bidhannagar, Kolkata, 700091, India
Authors with affiliations: Jha B.K., Birsa Agricultural University, Ranchi, Kanke, Jharkhand, 834008, India; Jha S.K., Birsa Agricultural University, Ranchi, Kanke, Jharkhand, 834008, India; Mukherjee R., Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, Bidhannagar, Kolkata, 700091, India; Basak D., Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, Bidhannagar, Kolkata, 700091, India
Abstract: Information technology (IT) has emerged as a boon to expedite the process of agricultural extension. The growth in mobile has surpassed internet due to cost effectiveness. Mobile as a tool holds promise for facilitating access of agricultural information by majority of the farmers. Its promotion has already been started by a few organizations, but mostly in supply mode. Hence, it was decided to develop the SMS based solution that works in demand mode. The solution consists of server stub and client stub. The server stub is a group of applications that receive surrogated query from client component in asynchronous mode and deliver desired information in flawless, efficient and uninterrupted manner. The server stub consists of message process, query process, database and analytical process. Client stub is a single application that is installed in user's mobile. The major functionalities of the client stub are: presentation and navigation, data management and message processing. In the implemented solution, total number of decision points and lists are 495 and 130 respectively. In list total number of elements varies from 2 to 15. The user selects information node from the list as per requirement. After selection of terminal node, message processing layer generates surrogated query which on confirmation is forwarded to Application Service Provider (ASP) end for processing. The solution has been developed for agriculture domain with crop, fertilizer, water management, crop protection, weather and agricultural implements as primary information area. © 2015 IEEE.

Author full names: Kontogiannis, Sotirios (36602849600); Tsipouras, Markos G. (6506315682); Kokkonis, George (54397103100); Godas, Dimitrios (57076912600); Valsamidis, Stavros (36603556700)
Title: Design and implementation of an identification productivity recording and breeding system for the sheep industry
Source title: International Journal of Sustainable Agricultural Management and Informatics
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece; Department of Business Administration, Technological Educational Institute of Western Macedonia, Grevena, 51100, Greece; Department of Accounting, Technological Educational Institution of East Macedonia and Thrace, Ag. Silas, Kavala, 65500, Greece
Abstract: This paper presents a new system architecture and test-bed application implementation called sheep manager. Sheep manager system uses near field communication (NFC) technology and custom NFC data exchange format records for the identification and attributes recording of sheep inside a flock. Sheep manager system also utilises sensors for real-time measurements and recording of raw milk extraction per ewe. All recorded information are then stored into an application server following an HTTP representational state transfer protocol specification. The authors also propose an algorithm for sheep breed selection that uses feedback information from past successful breeds in order to increase herd milk productivity. © 2016 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.

Authors: Steinberger G.; Rothmund M.; Auernhammer H.
Author full names: Steinberger, Georg (57192994642); Rothmund, Matthias (9843367900); Auernhammer, Hermann (6602132550)
Title: Mobile farm equipment as a data source in an agricultural service architecture
Source title: Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
Affiliations: Technical University Munich, Life Science Engineering Department, Agricultural Systems Engineering, D-85354 Freising, Am Staudengarten 2, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steinberger G., Technical University Munich, Life Science Engineering Department, Agricultural Systems Engineering, D-85354 Freising, Am Staudengarten 2, Germany; Rothmund M., Technical University Munich, Life Science Engineering Department, Agricultural Systems Engineering, D-85354 Freising, Am Staudengarten 2, Germany; Auernhammer H., Technical University Munich, Life Science Engineering Department, Agricultural Systems Engineering, D-85354 Freising, Am Staudengarten 2, Germany
Abstract: Information management is becoming an increasingly challenging task for farmers, especially in terms of the amount of data and the complexity of processes in precision farming. One of the most demanding functions is data acquisition. Mobile farm equipment featuring different sensors is able to collect a large amount of data while working. Automated process-data acquisition can be the basis for information-steered agricultural production. But use of these data is restricted today by hardware and software compatibility, different data formats, the lack of a concept for reusing data, and the amount of data. This paper presents a prototype implementation of an agricultural process-data service (APDS). It is part of an infrastructure for data management in information-driven plant production, developed in the Pre agro joint research project. Data are recorded in an ISOBUS environment and transferred to a server. There they are analyzed and aggregated to jobs. Data can be requested for further use via a web portal and a web service interface. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Simonis I.; Streit U.
Author full names: Simonis, Ingo (6507262129); Streit, Ulrich (6603866118)
Title: Mobile computing techniques coupled with distributed simulation and visualization systems to optimize the field data management
Source title: Bulletin of the Society of Cartographers
Affiliations: Institute for Geoinformatics, University of Muenster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Simonis I., Institute for Geoinformatics, University of Muenster, Germany; Streit U., Institute for Geoinformatics, University of Muenster, Germany
Abstract: The coupling of mobile computing techniques with spatial data infrastructures combined with the current developments in the communication and the simulation sector offer new options to realize a fast and cost effective field data management throughout the entire environmental sector (e.g. farming, forestry, geology, ecological planning etc.). To reduce the time, and hence the costs needed to acquire data in the field by hand, returning to the office, processing the data and eventually return to the field to do the indispensable measurement adjustments for optimal results, the improvements in the telecommunication sector are beneficial. The further integration of mobile clients into a Spatial Data Infrastructure, SDI, enable a direct access to urgently needed data that is stored on remote systems. Other corresponding SDI-components like WebMap-Server or WebCoverage-Server [OGC (2001a), and OGC (2000)] make it possible to requests processed data from the field, which allows a more efficient interpretation instantly.
Index Keywords: computer system; data acquisition; data processing; spatial data; visualization

Authors: Naito K.; Mori K.; Kobayashi H.
Author full names: Naito, Katsuhiro (8918889600); Mori, Kazuo (55368057400); Kobayashi, Hideo (55683277000)
Title: Implementation of agricultural sensor network systems based on Arduino based microcomputer board with bluetooth low energy
Source title: WMSCI 2015 - 19th World Multi-Conference on Systemics, Cybernetics and Informatics, Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Information Science, Aichi Institute of Technology, 1247 Yachigusa, Yakusa Cho, Toyota, 470-0392, Japan; Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mie University, 1577 Kurimamachiya, Tsu, 514-8507, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Naito K., Faculty of Information Science, Aichi Institute of Technology, 1247 Yachigusa, Yakusa Cho, Toyota, 470-0392, Japan; Mori K., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mie University, 1577 Kurimamachiya, Tsu, 514-8507, Japan; Kobayashi H., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mie University, 1577 Kurimamachiya, Tsu, 514-8507, Japan
Abstract: A sensor network in agricultural fields is a new technology to increase agricultural productivity by measuring important factors for plants such as air temperature, humidity, illumination intensity, soil moisture, soil temperature etc. The authors have been studied about some wireless sensor network systems, and have found that general microcomputer boards do not have enough performance to realize accurate measurements and stable wireless communication because they just consider the stable operation of their own electronic components, and do not assume practical external sensors and wireless communication modules. Therefore, a special design of microcomputer boards for sensor networks is required to develop practical agricultural sensor network systems. This paper proposes a new type of sensor network system for agricultural usages. The system consists of a new developed microcomputer board, a special smartphone application for data collection, and a data management server. The developed microcomputer board has special functions for a charging function from a solar cell to a lithium polymer battery, a large-current regulator for external electronic components, a capacitor for power supply stability, real-time clock (RTC), a power management for external sensors, a SD card support, and a communication function based on Bluetooth low energy (BLE). The special application supports BLE communication, which is a wireless personal area network technology for low-power communication. It also collects the measurement infor-mation from a developed microcomputer board within BLE communication range, and uploads the collected measurement information to the data management server. The benefit of the proposed system is accurate measurements with special external sensors for agricultural usages, and the easy installation of the microcomputer board by the autonomous operation and the easy data collection with the smartphone application.

Authors: Welte J.; Ault A.; Bowman C.; Ellis S.; Buckmaster D.; Ess D.; Krogmeier J.
Author full names: Welte, Jonathan (55823938900); Ault, Aaron (23491689300); Bowman, Cyrus (55823320600); Ellis, Steven (58427985700); Buckmaster, Dennis (6603935683); Ess, Daniel (35588221500); Krogmeier, James (7004262427)
Title: An approach to farm management information systems using task-specific, collaborative mobile apps and cloud storage services
Source title: American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers Annual International Meeting 2013, ASABE 2013
Affiliations: Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 225 S. University St., United States; Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 465 Northwestern Ave., United States
Authors with affiliations: Welte J., Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 225 S. University St., United States; Ault A., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 465 Northwestern Ave., United States; Bowman C., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 465 Northwestern Ave., United States; Ellis S., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 465 Northwestern Ave., United States; Buckmaster D., Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 225 S. University St., United States; Ess D., Agricultural and Biological Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 225 S. University St., United States; Krogmeier J., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, 465 Northwestern Ave., United States
Abstract: Modern production agriculture is beginning to advance beyond deterministic, scheduled operations between relatively few people to larger scale, information-driven efficiency in order to respond to the challenges of field variability and meet the needs of a growing population. Since no two farms are the same with respect to information and management structure, a specialized farm management information system (FMIS) which is tailored to the realities on the ground of individual farms is likely to be more effective than generalized FMIS available today. This paper presents the design and implementation of a novel distributed set of open-source, collaborative mobile apps known as Open Ag Toolkit (OpenATK). OpenATK endeavors to provide such a specialized FMIS solution by incorporating low-cost, widely available mobile computing technologies, internet-based cloud storage services, and user-centered design principles.
Author Keywords: Cloud storage; Data management; Distributed data model; Mobile apps; Usability
Index Keywords: Farms; Management information systems; Cloud storage services; Cloud storages; Design and implementations; Distributed data; Mobile apps; Mobile computing technology; Production agriculture; Usability; Information management

Authors: Ji R.; Wu C.; Li M.; Ye H.; Guo W.; Zheng L.
Title: Development and implementation of field information management system based on telecommunications
Source title: Nongye Gongcheng Xuebao/Transactions of the Chinese Society of Agricultural Engineering
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China; Institute of Remote Sensing and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100081, China
Authors with affiliations: Ji R., Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China; Wu C., Institute of Remote Sensing and GIS, Peking University, Beijing 100081, China; Li M., Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China; Ye H., Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China; Guo W., Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China; Zheng L., Key Laboratory of Modern Precision Agriculture System Integration Research, Ministry of Education, China Agricultural University, Beijing 100083, China
Abstract: Remote intelligent management meet the needs of precision agriculture development. Field Information Management System was designed and realized in accordance with the thinking of software engineering. As an important component of Mobile Field Information Intelligent Service System, Field Information Management System was the core of field information intelligent management. Field Information Management System received the real-time field information from the wireless mobile terminals (that is field PDA) through GPRS, and stored them into the field information database. The field information was visualized, analyzed, and processed according to the field information process model, and provided support for the decision-making in field variable control. According to the primary functions of Field Information Management System, the system was divided into 4 modules, which were the map management module, the mobile terminals management module, the data management module and the system management module. Field information is real-time collected, transmitted, processed, and visualized in Field Information Management System, providing comprehensive decision information and technical support for users.

Authors: Nandyala C.S.; Kim H.-K.
Author full names: Nandyala, Chandra Sukanya (57160181200); Kim, Haeng-Kon (8835787400)
Title: Big and meta data management for U-Agriculture mobile services
Source title: International Journal of Software Engineering and its Applications
Affiliations: Department of IT Engineering, Catholic University Of Daegu, South Korea; Department of Computer Engineering, Catholic University of Daegu, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Nandyala C.S., Department of IT Engineering, Catholic University Of Daegu, South Korea; Kim H.-K., Department of Computer Engineering, Catholic University of Daegu, South Korea
Abstract: Big Data is a huge amount of data generated continuously and it extracts the meaning, structure, and relationships in enormously large data sets. Metadata is defined as data about data, where is comes from, and when it was taken etc. Metadata is a supplementary data and is generally related with a certain piece of data (big data) that is more important. Metadata helps in making value added decisions and information about own data travelling for big data. This paper communicates about big data, metadata and their management associated to U-Agriculture mobile services and lime lights more on sensors that are integrated and Built-In. B & M (Big and Meta) data management is very challenging and is strong topic for research currently. Firstly, this paper reviews B & M data and their management. Also presents relationship between big data and Metadata and challenges. And also types of sensors, techniques, technologies, applications, and advantages of various types of sensors for U-Agriculture mobile services in their decision making. Finally presents architecture for U-Agriculture Mobile Services based on Sensor-Cloud Infrastructure which helps not only farms and also applications, services provides and organisations in management of B & M data. © 2016 SERSC.

Authors: Marx S.A.; Luck J.D.
Title: Assessing accuracy of machine CAN bus data using SAE J1939 and Nebraska tractor test laboratory data
Source title: American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers Annual International Meeting 2014, ASABE 2014
Affiliations: University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Department of Biological Systems Engineering, 206 L.W. Chase Hall, Lincoln, 68583, NE, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marx S.A., University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Department of Biological Systems Engineering, 206 L.W. Chase Hall, Lincoln, 68583, NE, United States; Luck J.D., University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Department of Biological Systems Engineering, 206 L.W. Chase Hall, Lincoln, 68583, NE, United States
Abstract: There has been a growing trend in public and private groups focusing on data utilization in agricultural settings in the U.S. over the past five years. This information, typically referred to as Precision Agriculture (PA) data, has advanced from field collected data (e.g., yield and soil samples) to data that many producers may never see. Controller Area Network (CAN) Bus is one example of data rarely perceived by those operating field machinery; however it is crucial to the machine functionality. This information is becoming more widely used by groups (manufacturers, dealerships, and data management companies) seeking to utilize these data for realtime applications including machine diagnostics, machine health monitoring, and field efficiency estimations. The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) J1939 standard messages utilized by the machine CAN Bus have theoretical values, however little work has been done to verify these values. For example, fuel flow rate values reported are rarely measured directly on field equipment using a flow meter, and must be therefore estimated based on other operating parameters. The goal of this study was to compare data collected from the CAN Bus to measured values from tests conducted at the Nebraska Tractor Test Laboratory (NTTL), an approved OECD Test Station to provide an indication of accuracy among the measured values. A National Instruments LabView program was written to simultaneously log CAN Bus messages along with the NTTL test data. Selected parameters from the SAE J1939 message data base were then compared with actual steady-state values measured during testing. Results from this study will provided needed information regarding the accuracy of certain messages being passed on the CAN Bus. This will give end users the ability to assess potential errors that may exist when the CAN Bus is utilized as a data source for further analysis during real-life scenarios of machine utilization. As initial results indicate, the CAN based fuel rate is measured higher than actual fuel rate, so more data collection will be required to find the correlation to aid in a more accurate assessment of in field efficiency measured via CAN bus.

Authors: Djorgovski S.G.
Author full names: Djorgovski, S.G. (7005199582)
Title: Virtual astronomy, information technology, and the new scientific methodology
Source title: Proceedings - International Workshop on Computer Architecture for Machine Perception, CAMP
Affiliations: California Institute of Technology, United States; Division of Physics, Mathematics, and Astronomy, Center for Advanced Computing Research, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Center for Advanced Computing Research at Caltech, United States; Department of Astronomy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Djorgovski S.G., California Institute of Technology, United States, Division of Physics, Mathematics, and Astronomy, Center for Advanced Computing Research, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States, Center for Advanced Computing Research at Caltech, United States, Department of Astronomy, United States
Abstract: All sciences, including astronomy, are now entering the era of information abundance. The exponentially increasing volume and complexity of modern data sets promises to transform the scientific practice, but also poses a number of common technological challenges. The Virtual Observatory concept is the astronomical community's response to these challenges: it aims to harness the progress in information technology in the service of astronomy, and at the same time provide a valuable testbed for information technology and applied computer science. Challenges broadly fall into two categories: data handling (or "data farming"), including issues such as archives, intelligent storage, databases, interoperability, fast networks, etc., and data mining, data understanding, and knowledge discovery, which include issues such as automated clustering and classification, multivariate correlation searches, pattern recognition, visualization in highly hyperdimensional parameter spaces, etc., as well as various applications of machine learning in these contexts. Such techniques are forming a methodological foundation for science with massive and complex data sets in general, and are likely to have a much broather impact on the modern society, commerce, information economy, security, etc. There is a powerful emerging synergy between the computationally enabled science and the science-driven computing, which will drive the progress in science, scholarship, and many other venues in the 21st century. © 2005 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Astronomy; Data management; Information technology; Knowledge acquisition; Knowledge representation; Scientific visualization

Authors: Cressman K.
Author full names: Cressman, Keith (6506372753)
Title: Desert Locust
Source title: Biological and Environmental Hazards, Risks, and Disasters
Affiliations: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cressman K., Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The desert locust is considered to be the most dangerous of all migratory pest species in the world due to its ability to reproduce rapidly, migrate long distances, and devastate crops. In order to minimize the frequency, severity, and duration of plagues, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations operates a global early warning system based on the latest technological advances that have led to dramatic improvements in data management, analysis, and forecasting. The system can be a model for other early warning systems about migratory pests. © 2016 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors with affiliations: Vavoulidou E., National Agricultural Research Foundation (NAGREF), Soil Science Institute of Athens, Athens, Greece; Charoulis A., NAGREF, Institute of Soil Mapping and Classification, Larissa, Greece; Soulis K., Agricultural University of Athens, Division of Water Resources Management, Athens, Greece; Karyotis T., NAGREF, Institute of Soil Mapping and Classification, Larissa, Greece; Kavvadias V., National Agricultural Research Foundation (NAGREF), Soil Science Institute of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: A soil survey and classification program was carried out over a 5.86-ha agricultural area in the wider region of Malia in the island of Crete. The spatial data from the soil survey were organized using a geographic information system (GIS) to facilitate storage, management, and analysis. In the first stage, the available data for the study were collected, digitized, and processed (maps, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs). Based on this information, many other derivative data layers such as slope, curvature, and slope aspect were manipulated. Sampling points were determined with GIS, while the exact position of each sampling was recorded using a global positioning system (GPS). This information, along with results pertaining to the sample, was entered into the graphical database, which was specially designed to store all the relevant data of the sampled points. Data layers describing the spatial distribution of key parameters such as soil texture, pH, calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and nutrient status were produced. The use of GIS was very helpful for soil classification and evaluation of soil suitability for a range of activities, whereas the visualization of the data collected and the derived results in the form of various thematic maps demonstrated the ability of GIS to act as a valuable administrative tool and, in addition, to provide substantial valuable support to farmers in improving the applied farming practices. Copyright © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Banhazi T.M.
Author full names: Banhazi, Thomas M. (12785390200)
Title: User-friendly air quality monitoring system
Source title: Applied Engineering in Agriculture
Affiliations: Livestock System Alliance, University of Adelaide, Roseworthy, SA 5371, Roseworthy Campus, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Banhazi T.M., Livestock System Alliance, University of Adelaide, Roseworthy, SA 5371, Roseworthy Campus, Australia
Abstract: A user-friendly version of the scientific environmental monitoring kit used in Australia during a large air quality (AQ) study was created to enable routine environmental assessment in commercial livestock buildings and thus improve building environments and reduce pollutant emissions. The objective of the study was to produce a reliable and cost-effective hardware and software system for measuring six key environmental variables. The main components of the "BASE-Q" system are the two measurement boxes containing the sensors; the internet-based PC and pocket PC-based softwares; and the Users' Manual detailing recommended monitoring procedures. The first BASE-Q box contains sensors for measuring air temperature (AT), relative humidity (RH), the concentrations of ammonia (NH3) and carbon dioxide (CO2) up to 10-30 days depending on the logging interval. The second contains a vacuum pump and Venturi tubes and is used to measure concentrations of inhalable and respirable particles gravimetrically over an 8- to 10-h period. Engineering characteristics of the buildings are recorded on site and the collected data stored and processed by the internet or PC-based BASE-Q program. The program automatically calculates the concentrations and emission rates of the different airborne pollutants from individual buildings by using prediction models developed during related studies as a pre-screening exercise before actual measurements are undertaken. The size and weight of the monitoring hardware have been markedly reduced to improve ease of installation and transport. The monitoring equipment has been simplified and waterproofed to improve ease of deployment and disinfection. The special software has greatly simplified data management and reporting. These improvements have reduced the labor input required for operating the system and thus minimized the cost of AQ monitoring. This will enable producers and consultants to measure AQ routinely on farms, reducing worker OH&S risks, improving environmental outcomes, and potentially improving production efficiency. © 2009 American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers.

Authors: Sun X.; Wu B.; Li Q.; Wu H.; Chen C.
Title: The study of farmers' professional cooperatives information service system
Source title: Proceedings - 2013 International Conference on Computer Sciences and Applications, CSA 2013
Affiliations: Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, China; Beijing Research Center for Information Technology in Agriculture, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun X., Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, China, Beijing Research Center for Information Technology in Agriculture, Beijing, China; Wu B., Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, China; Li Q., Beijing Research Center for Information Technology in Agriculture, Beijing, China; Wu H., Beijing Research Center for Information Technology in Agriculture, Beijing, China; Chen C., Beijing Research Center for Information Technology in Agriculture, Beijing, China
Abstract: Application of intelligent information processing technology which takes active role in goods production and circulation is an effective way to enhance the comprehensive management capabilities of Professional Farmers Cooperatives. The key breakthrough technologies, such as information aggregated data management, data transfer information management, information customization and intelligent push techniques, helped to build the Information System of Professional Farmers Cooperatives. The system consists of two levels of service architecture. Server terminal port, including information comprehensive platform integrated with agricultural search engine, provides network convergence of various information, market propaganda and information customization services. Client terminal provides social business management, production monitoring, market analysis, purchase and sale archives management and membership management services. The system offers a docking platform between technology and market information, providing an information service solution with high efficiency service and management and low operating cost for Professional Farmers Cooperatives. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Bai L.-S.; Feng Z.-K.; Wang J.; Xiong N.-N.
Title: Design and realization of forestry resources surveying and management system
Source title: Beijing Linye Daxue Xuebao/Journal of Beijing Forestry University
Affiliations: Tsinghua Sunway Survey Co. Ltd., Beijing 100085, China; Institute of GIS RS and GPS, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China
Authors with affiliations: Bai L.-S., Tsinghua Sunway Survey Co. Ltd., Beijing 100085, China, Institute of GIS RS and GPS, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China; Feng Z.-K., Institute of GIS RS and GPS, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China; Wang J., Institute of GIS RS and GPS, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China; Xiong N.-N., Institute of GIS RS and GPS, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China
Abstract: To avoid inaccurate data, inefficient work and inconsistent information in traditional surveying method, a forestry resources surveying and management information system was designed using geographic information system, global positioning system and remote sensing (usually called 3S). The system includes three models: data collection, data disposal and data management. It is one of the best solution schemes for forestry surveying and management based on national industry standards.

Authors: Coulon-Leroy C.; Charnomordic B.; Thiollet-Scholtus M.; Guillaume S.
Author full names: Coulon-Leroy, Cécile (55522280500); Charnomordic, Brigitte (6507898222); Thiollet-Scholtus, Marie (51566028300); Guillaume, Serge (7003700410)
Title: Imperfect knowledge and data-based approach to model a complex agronomic feature - Application to vine vigor
Source title: Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
Affiliations: INRA UE1117, UMT Vinitera, 49071 Beaucouzé, France; INRA Supagro, UMR MISTEA, 34060 Montpellier, France; Irstea, UMR ITAP, 34196 Montpellier, France
Authors with affiliations: Coulon-Leroy C., INRA UE1117, UMT Vinitera, 49071 Beaucouzé, France; Charnomordic B., INRA Supagro, UMR MISTEA, 34060 Montpellier, France; Thiollet-Scholtus M., INRA UE1117, UMT Vinitera, 49071 Beaucouzé, France; Guillaume S., Irstea, UMR ITAP, 34196 Montpellier, France
Abstract: Vine vigor, a key agronomic parameter, depends on environmental factors but also on agricultural practices. The goal of this paper is to model vine vigor level according to the most influential variables. The approach was based upon a collected dataset in a French vineyard in the middle Loire valley and the available expert knowledge. The input features were related to soil, rootstock and inter-crop management, the output was an expert assessment of vine plot vigor. The approach included a data selection step, which was needed because of data imperfection and incompleteness. Usually implicit in the literature, data selection was carried out with explicit criteria. Then a fuzzy model was designed from the selected data. Owing to the fuzzy model interpretability, its structure and behavior were analyzed. Results showed that, despite the data imperfection, the approach was able to select data that yielded an informative model. Well-known relationships were identified, and some elements of new or controversial knowledge were discussed. This is an important step towards the design of a decision support tool aiming to adapt the agricultural practices to the environment in order to get a given vigor level. © 2013 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Automatic learning; Data inconsistency; Data selection; Fuzzy logic; Hidden variables; Knowledge imprecision

Funding Texts: This work is part of a PhD project that aims to study the combined effects of environmental factors and agricultural practices and link them with wine quality. The first author received a fellowship from the ‘INRA-SAD’ department and Pays de la Loire Region (France). We are grateful to ‘La Cave des Vignerons de Saumur’ to make data available to us for this study.

Authors: Mills A.
Title: Small islands spatial data infrastructure
Source title: GEO: connexion
Abstract: A group of UK Overseas Territory (UKOT) and the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States are relying on geographic information system (GIS) for Spatial Data Infrastructure (SDI) for data quality and control, information sharing and delivering finished products for use between governmental agencies and private organizations. UKOT has implemented GIS since 2005 to synthesize dissimilar databases and datasets and create new maps and images for environmental management. The system works using ArcView, a component of Arc GIS Desktop, which has a flexible framework that accepts new monitoring data. GIS is also used by the Agriculture and Natural Resources Department (ANRD) along with St Helena National Trust (SHNT), which implemented ArcView and a Microsoft Access database to monitor clearance of invasive flax and other plants and manage the growth of widespread cabbage trees and tree ferns in St. Helena. GIS is used to evaluate land resources for St. Kitts, the smallest independent state in the western hemisphere.
Index Keywords: Atlantic islands; Atlantic Ocean; Saint Helena; Brassica oleracea var. capitata; Filicophyta; Linum usitatissimum; data management; data quality; database; environmental management; fern; GIS; infrastructure; island; mapping method; monocotyledon; spatial data

Authors: Suprem A.; Mahalik N.; Kim K.
Author full names: Suprem, Abhijit (55512698100); Mahalik, Nitaigour (9842982100); Kim, Kiseon (7409322031)
Title: A review on application of technology systems, standards and interfaces for agriculture and food sector
Source title: Computer Standards and Interfaces
Affiliations: Lyles College of Engineering, California State University, Fresno, United States; Jordan College of Agricultural Sciences and Technology, California State University, Fresno, United States; School of Communication and Sensor Networks, Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Suprem A., Lyles College of Engineering, California State University, Fresno, United States; Mahalik N., Jordan College of Agricultural Sciences and Technology, California State University, Fresno, United States; Kim K., School of Communication and Sensor Networks, Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, South Korea
Abstract: Application of technology systems is seen in many sectors including agriculture and food. Traditionally, agricultural industry has been solely dependent on human labor with limited application of mechanical equipment and machines. The applications of advanced technology such as embedded computing, robotics, wireless technology, GPS/GIS (Geographical Positioning System/Geographical Information System) and DBMS (Database Management System) software are seen to be recent developments. This paper reviews the applications of technology systems in agriculture and food. Because knowledge on standardization and interfacing plays a key role in using the technology systems in any application domain, this paper aims to highlight the important attributes of such an emerging research area. In particular, the paper describes soil sampling methods and technology applications; field and yield mapping with GPS and GIS; harvesters and future research in robotic-based harvesters; food processing and packaging technology such as traceability and status of RFID networking research; application of sensor network; data management and execution systems; and the automation and control standards such as fieldbus systems and OMAC guidelines. © 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bareth G.; Yu Z.R.
Author full names: Bareth, Georg (6505760587); Yu, ZhenRong (7404346997)
Title: Availability of digital geodata in China; [Verfügbarkeit von digitalen Geodaten in China]
Source title: Petermanns Geographische Mitteilungen
Affiliations: Universität zu Köln, Geographisches Institut, Albertus-Magnus-Platz, Köln 50923, Germany; China Agricultural University, Coll. of Agric. Rsrc./Environ. Sci., Beijing 100094, China
Authors with affiliations: Bareth G., Universität zu Köln, Geographisches Institut, Albertus-Magnus-Platz, Köln 50923, Germany; Yu Z.R., China Agricultural University, Coll. of Agric. Rsrc./Environ. Sci., Beijing 100094, China
Abstract: Applying a GIS to spatial problems is a well-established method in research, planning and administration. The availability of digital geodata for modelling various spatial problems is a key issue in the establishment of a proper GIS. In China, the application of GIS technologies is widespread. Due to data policy, knowledge of the availability of digital geodata is rather scarce. In the literature, most of the applications described for China deal with data which are ≤1:1,000,000. There is no comprehensive knowledge of existing data at the meso- and microscale in China. In the context of a specific research programme of several years' duration in China, as a side-effect of data acquisition information could be gathered on the availability of such data. Whereas micro-level data are not accessible due to data policy, there is a chance for international cooperation projects to obtain and work with data on topography, soils, land use, climate and socio-economic issues at the in meso-scale in China itself.
Author Keywords: Agriculture; China; Climate; Data; GIS; Land use; Soil; Topography; Weather
Index Keywords: Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East; data management; GIS; land use; topography

Authors: Harrison P.R.; Ann Harrison P.; Kimes D.S.
Author full names: Harrison, Patrick R. (7401612272); Ann Harrison, P. (25937631200); Kimes, Daniel S. (56277695700)
Title: VEG: Intelligent workbench for studying earth's vegetation
Source title: Expert Systems With Applications
Affiliations: U.S. Naval Academy, United States; Intellicorp, Inc., United States; NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harrison P.R., U.S. Naval Academy, United States; Ann Harrison P., Intellicorp, Inc., United States; Kimes D.S., NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe VEG, an intelligent workbench for remote sensing scientists. VEG assists scientists in the analysis of optical reflectance data. VEG was designed to manage complexity, provide intelligent support, provide visualization tools, and contract the time required for a scientist studying the earth's vegetation to run exploratory studies, test alternative hypotheses, do what if thinking, and manage large data sets. VEG organizes and provides coherence to a diverse set of techniques and tools that are used by these scientists. It codifies in knowledge-based system components, heuristic knowledge used by these scientists when doing scientific work. The VEG system saves the scientist many hours of laborious calculation, and it empowers the scientist by allowing him or her to work quickly at a higher level of abstraction without the need to focus attention on a multitude of low-level tasks. The VEG system includes rule-based components, data management tools, technique design and management tools, browsers, graphics support, a highly visual interface, and a system for organizing and managing problem histories. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Calculations; Heuristic methods; History; Information analysis; Remote sensing; Research; Research and development management; Visualization; Browsers; Data management tools; Exploratory studies; Graphics support; Heuristic knowledge; Optical reflectance data analysis; Scientists; Vegetation; Expert systems

Authors: Aronoff S.
Title: Geographic information systems: a management perspective
Source title: Geographic information systems: a management perspective
Abstract: The geographic information system (GIS) has dramatically changed the rate at which georeferenced data can be produced, updated, and disseminated. It has made the production and analysis of geographic information more efficient, and has changed the way this information is perceived and used. GISes now play an essential role in the management of land resources from the local to the global scale, from municipal planning to natural resource assessment. Provides a concise and practical introduction to the use of GIS technology. General concepts are introduced with examples that show a wide range of applications including agriculture, land use planning, mining exploration, and municipal information management. A chapter is devoted to the fundamentals of remote sensing, which has become a major GIS data source. The procedures and equipment used for data input and output are reviewed. Data quality, data management, and GIS analysis functions are presented and, finally, the process of GIS implementation is examined. -after Author
Index Keywords: digitising; Geographical Information Systems; georeferenced data; GIS analysis; GIS implementation; GIS technology; global scale; land resources management; municipal information management; municipal planning; natural resources assessment; remote sensing

Authors: Jacucci G.; Foy M.; Uhrik C.
Author full names: Jacucci, Gianni (6701526082); Foy, Mark (7003968803); Uhrik, Carl (6603451638)
Title: Developing transportable agricultural decision support systems: Part 2. An example
Source title: Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
Affiliations: Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipto. di Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy; University of Phoenix, DTP Faculty, Englewood, CO 80111, 7800 E. Dorado Pl., United States; Boulder, CO 80302-5563, 1818 19th Street No. 309, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jacucci G., Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipto. di Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy; Foy M., Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipto. di Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy, Boulder, CO 80302-5563, 1818 19th Street No. 309, United States; Uhrik C., University of Phoenix, DTP Faculty, Englewood, CO 80111, 7800 E. Dorado Pl., United States
Abstract: Information in the area of developing transportable decision support systems (DSSs) (agricultural or otherwise) has been scarce. Therefore, developers of DSSs have had some difficulties in constructing DSSs which could be widely used. In the first part of this two-part paper series, a conceptual framework was introduced which proposes methods for making DSSs transportable. This framework serves as a checklist and includes recommendations about general implementation, user interaction, data management, and model aspects. To illustrate the implementation of these recommendations, the development of a DSS within a project called SYBIL is discussed in detail. Therein, portable and public domain tools have been used to build the DSS with a graphical user interface (GUI) which satisfies the general implementation aspects of the framework. Further, the development of a flexible data management system has been essential in the project so that different types of data can be easily handled without changing the models. In order to allow models embedded within the DSS to be successfully transported between regions, a novel artificial intelligence (AI) adaptation methodology was implemented. The main component of this adaptation methodology is a genetic algorithm (GA), an AI search technique. By linking a GA to an agricultural model, the model becomes more robust because the model is able to adapt to the region in which it is being used. Overall, by using the framework criteria to select/create these tools/components, the DSS has been made easy to transport and disseminate.
Author Keywords: Adaptation; Decision support system; Genetic algorithm; Modeling; Portability
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Artificial intelligence; Computer simulation; Computer software portability; Genetic algorithms; Graphical user interfaces; Human computer interaction; Information management; Adaptation; Agricultural decision support systems; Decision support systems

Authors: King Roger L.
Author full names: King, Roger L. (24565319100)
Title: Challenge for high spatial, spectral, and temporal resolution data fusion
Source title: International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States
Authors with affiliations: King Roger L., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi State, United States
Abstract: The Remote Sensing Technologies Center (RSTC) at Mississippi State University (MSU) is investigating the application of high-resolution imagery in the areas of precision agriculture, forest resource management, and environmental assessments of transportation systems. For precision agriculture, the focus of the research is to develop the expertise to utilize this imagery to facilitate management decisions at the farm level. Decision making at the farm level requires high spatial resolution imagery (on the order of 1 meter or less) in order to develop prescriptions for nutrient supplements, integrated pest management (insects, weeds), irrigation, and to serve as a harvesting aid. This degree of analysis of the plant and soil also requires that higher spectral resolution be available to ascertain the nuances in the target vegetation's reflectance and to be able to relate this to specific agricultural problems. In addition, decisions at the farm level must be made within a few days of onset of a problem. Therefore, revisit frequencies for precision agriculture are on the order of 10-14 days. The requirement for high spatial, spectral, and temporal resolution imagery creates special image processing and analysis challenges. These include - data management, geometric & radiometric corrections, ground control points & georeferencing, and data analysis via such approaches as data fusion. The purpose of this paper is twofold. First, to illustrate the diversity of high spatial, spectral, and temporal resolution imagery required for precision agriculture applications. Second, to offer the opportunity to other data fusion researchers to join the author of this paper in developing new data fusion techniques for high-resolution imagery.
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Decision making; Environmental engineering; Forestry; Image sensors; Plants (botany); Sensor data fusion; Soils; Vegetation; High-resolution imagery; Remote sensing
Conference name: 2000 Internaitonal Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS 2000)
Abbreviated Source Title: Dig Int Geosci Remote Sens Symp (IGARSS)

Authors: Doraiswamy P.C.; Pasteris P.A.; Jones K.C.; Motha R.P.; Nejedlik P.
Title: Techniques for methods of collection, database management and distribution of agrometeorological data
Source title: Agricultural and Forest Meteorology
Affiliations: U. States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Beltsville, MD 2075, United States; U. States Department of Agriculture, Nat. Rsrc. Conserv. Serv., Natl. W., Portland, OR, United States; U. States Department of Agriculture, World Agric. Outlook Bd., Jt. A., Washington, DC, United States; Slovak Hydrometeorological Institute, Kosice, Slovakia
Authors with affiliations: Doraiswamy P.C., U. States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Beltsville, MD 2075, United States; Pasteris P.A., U. States Department of Agriculture, Nat. Rsrc. Conserv. Serv., Natl. W., Portland, OR, United States; Jones K.C., U. States Department of Agriculture, Nat. Rsrc. Conserv. Serv., Natl. W., Portland, OR, United States; Motha R.P., U. States Department of Agriculture, World Agric. Outlook Bd., Jt. A., Washington, DC, United States; Nejedlik P., Slovak Hydrometeorological Institute, Kosice, Slovakia
Abstract: The major concerns for the availability of climate and agrometeorological data as we move into the 21st century continue to be in areas of data collection and data base management. New technologies have advanced our ability to address these issues but the solutions may require the commitment of resources that may yet be outside the reach of developing countries. This paper briefly reviews new and existing technologies in the areas of data collection methods with some emphasis on remote sensing methods. An example for a conceptual data base management system adapted by the US Department of Agriculture is presented as a framework for the acquisition, maintenance and distribution of climate and agrometeorological data for the 21st century. The access of data to the national and international community can be resolved with the standardization of data base management and electronic accessibility. Databases in the US have been upgraded for access through the World Wide Web, and include data archived from other countries that have co-operative programs with US institutions. The operational needs of national agricultural producers, researchers, and agricultural weather and crop forecasters are the focus of this paper although it also serves some of the needs of the international research community. Authors: Jacucci G.; Foy M.; Uhrik C.
Author full names: Jacucci, Gianni (6701526082); Foy, Mark (7003968803); Uhrik, Carl (6603451638)
Title: Developing transportable agricultural decision support systems: Part 1. A conceptual framework
Source title: Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
Affiliations: Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipartimemo Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy; University of Phoenix, DTP Faculty, Englewood, CO 80111, 7800 E. Authors with affiliations: Jacucci G., Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipartimemo Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy; Foy M., Lab. di Ingegneria Informatica, Dipartimemo Info. e Studi Aziendali, Univ. degli Studi di Trento, 38068 Rovereto (TN), Via Fortunato Zeni 8, Italy, Boulder, CO 80302-5563, 1818 19th Street No. 309, United States; Uhrik C., University of Phoenix, DTP Faculty, Englewood, CO 80111, 7800 E. Dorado Pl., United States
Abstract: Developers of agricultural decision support systems (DSSs) have had little guidance in constructing DSSs which could be widely used. To assist, a conceptual framework is introduced which proposes methods for making DSSs transportable so that their utility is high. This framework serves as a checklist and includes recommendations about general implementation, user interaction, data management, and models. General implementation aspects emphasize portable and public domain tools, and user interaction aspects the use of a graphical user interface (GUI); flexible data management systems play a large role in satisfying the suggested data management aspects; and an intelligent model adaptation strategy is one of the main model aspect recommendations.

Authors: Strapp J.D.; Keller C.P.
Author full names: Strapp, James D. (14625483100); Keller, C. Peter (7201710900)
Title: Towards an interactive spatial decision support system for agricultural land consolidation
Source title: Geographical Systems
Affiliations: Coopers and Lybrand, London, WC2N 6NN, 1 Embankment Place, United Kingdom; Department of Geography, School for Earth and Ocean Sciences, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC V8W 3P5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Strapp J.D., Coopers and Lybrand, London, WC2N 6NN, 1 Embankment Place, United Kingdom; Keller C.P., Department of Geography, School for Earth and Ocean Sciences, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC V8W 3P5, Canada
Abstract: Advances in GIS technology present the opportunity to move traditional quantitative approaches to spatial decision making from rigid quantitative modelling to more interactive spatial decision support that includes qualitative parameters and subjective viewpoints. This paper describes a new approach to a complex spatial assignment problem that has resisted traditional optimization techniques. The many diverse quantitative and qualitative objectives underlying agricultural land consolidation are enumerated and formalized. The design of an interactive multiple objective solution approach that takes advantage of the visualization and data management capabilities of commercially available GIS is explained. Experiences gained when demonstrating the SDSS in a pilot study conducted in the Czech Republic are reported. © 1996 OPA (Overseas Publishers Association) Amsterdam B. V. Published in The Netherlands under license by Gordon and Breach Science Publishers SA.
Author Keywords: Agriculture; Interactive solutions; Land consolidation; Spatial decision support system
