Authors: Usery E.L.; Pocknee S.; Boydell B.
Title: Precision farming data management using geographic information systems
Source title: Photogrammetric Engineering & Remote Sensing
Abstract: To manage spatial variability, modern farmers are looking for advanced technological solutions. Management strategies incorporating remote sensing, the Global Positioning System (GPS), and variable rate treatment (VRT) offer the possibility of positioning inputs exactly in order to optimize farm returns and minimize chemical inputs and environmental hazards. The use of geographic information systems (GIS) is essential for such a management paradigm. This paper introduces the concept of precision farming and discusses the role of GIS as a centralized data management and analysis tool. Results from a survey of the use of GIS in precision farming are included in order to determine strengths and weaknesses of the technology and to provide impetus for improvements in GIS to support agricultural applications. -Authors
Index Keywords: farming data management; GIS; GPS; variable rate treatment

Authors: Bruce MacDonald K.; Russell L.R.
Author full names: Bruce MacDonald, K. (24382476000); Russell, Linda R. (7202252280)
Title: A method to determine the computer system requirements for a large-scale geographic information system (GIS)
Source title: Computers and Electronics in Agriculture
Affiliations: Canada; The Laurier Group, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5H9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bruce MacDonald K., Canada; Russell L.R., The Laurier Group, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5H9, Canada
Abstract: Since 1972, Agriculture Canada has used automated means of maintaining soil information. The Canada Soil Information System (CanSIS), developed by Agriculture Canada, has allowed for the capture of spatial data in computer-readable format (both digitized line information and keyed text data) and has provided data management, manipulation, analysis and output capabilities. In recent years, soil surveyors and other users of CanSIS have become aware that other Geographic Information Systems (GIS) offered features which they required but which CanSIS did not provide. A review of commercially available GIS's provided adequate information to confirm their functional capabilities but not the computer capacity requirements in terms relevant to the Agriculture Canada application. This article explains how the computer capacity requirements were measured and used to develop specifications of a suitable system. The methodology is not restricted to GIS applications but can be used to determine the capacity needs of other software packages. © 1989.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Engineering--Canada; Computer Operating Systems--Storage Allocation; Computer Software; Geographic Information System; Maps and Mapping

Authors: Puers B.; Wouters P.; De Cooman M.
Title: A low power multi-channel sensor interface for use in digital telemetry
Source title: Sensors and Actuators: A. Physical
Affiliations: Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Departement Elektrotechniek, ESAT-MICAS, B-3001 Heverlee, Kardinaal Mercierlaan 94, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Puers B., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Departement Elektrotechniek, ESAT-MICAS, B-3001 Heverlee, Kardinaal Mercierlaan 94, Belgium; Wouters P., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Departement Elektrotechniek, ESAT-MICAS, B-3001 Heverlee, Kardinaal Mercierlaan 94, Belgium; De Cooman M., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Departement Elektrotechniek, ESAT-MICAS, B-3001 Heverlee, Kardinaal Mercierlaan 94, Belgium
Abstract: A novel telemetry transponder is presented for application in an extensive animal monitoring and climatic control system. It contains an identification code and collects information on physiological parameters related to health and welfare of the individual animal. A dedicated low power CMOS transponder microchip is developed. Emphasis is on a high degree of flexibility towards sensor inputs and internal data management, and extreme miniaturization and low power consumption to allow implantation. © 1993.

Title: GIS for the 1990s. Proceedings of a national conference, Ottawa, March 1990
Abstract: Geographic information systems have applications across a wide spectrum of disciplines and it seems likely their usage will increase in the future. This book contains 142 papers (11 in French) addressing the latest developments and expected trends in the GIS field for the next decade. Various themes are addressed in separate sections including: applications of GIS for environmental modelling, municipal management, data management, geosciences, communications, forestry, resource management, agriculture, and water management; data management issues; database design; GIS education and training; remote sensing data integration; marketing and economic analysis; research and development issues. Case studies of specific GIS applications are presented. Papers are also abstracted separately in Geographical Abstracts. -N.Davey
Index Keywords: agriculture; data management; education; environmental modelling; forestry; GIS; research and development; resource management; technological application; training; water
Publisher: Canadian Institute of Surveying & Mapping, Ottawa

Authors: Brignall P.; Parry M.; Porter J.
Title: GIS and the impacts of climate change
Source title: Mapping Awareness & GIS Europe
Abstract: Attempts to assess the possible impact of climate change on agriculture and natural ecosystems are increasingly drawing upon GIS in order to gain the regional and national picture required for policy-relevant results. This article illustrates some recent GIS-based assessments conducted by the Atmospheric Impacts Research (AIR) Group at present based in the School of Geography at the University of Birmingham but which will shortly be moving to the University of Oxford's new Environmental Change Unit. New European projects have a much larger data requirement which will need data management. -from Authors
Index Keywords: climate change; GIS; natural ecosystem
